messages.content:
Custom tokens is a powerful feature of Mina Protocol, supporting fungible token on the protocol level.

NFT can be implemented using solutions like zkfs but this discussion is to discuss the possibility on using custom tokens for NFT standard.
This was discussed in the last community call and I looked further into custom tokens but so far could not figure out a way to make that happen.
This post is to discuss if it can be achieved and the ways it might be done.

Relevant resources: https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/tutorials/custom-tokens
https://github.com/o1-labs/snarkyjs/blob/main/src/examples/zkapps/token_with_proofs.ts

embeds.title: Mina Documentation
embeds.description: Website for documentation about Mina Protocol

embeds.title: snarkyjs/src/examples/zkapps/token_with_proofs.ts at main Â· o1-labs...
embeds.description: TypeScript framework for zk-SNARKs and zkApps. Contribute to o1-labs/snarkyjs development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: What exactly are you trying to achieve and what problems did you run into?

I'm pretty familiar with custom tokens since i've built the following standard draft for fungible tokens:
https://github.com/stove-labs/mip-token-standard/issues/2

embeds.title: Token standard definition Â· Issue #2 Â· stove-labs/mip-token-standard
embeds.description: This Issue contains a WIP token standard definition for the Mina L1, built with snarkyjs and based on the currently available smart contract features such as custom tokens. As a result of this disc...

messages.content: Custom tokens are built fungible in nature. I could not find a way make in non-fungible to create NFT collection.
Why not? you'll simply disallow minting of more than 1 of the token

Yes. Let's take this scenario.
User A mints token 1.
User B mints token 2.
User B transfers token 2 to User A.

Now User A holds both token 1 and token 2.

How can token 1 and token 2 be differentiated?
by their built-in token ID, both are their own contracts and have an associated tokenId + address which are unique
in this case, how would a transfer of NFT work?
same as of the fungible token, whats the difference?

I might have been unclear on what I said above. Let me elaborate further on the above scenario. This is what I had in mind.
User A is the deployer. 
1. User A generates key pair (secret_key, public_key). For the given key pair, it will have the fixed `tokenId`.
2. Since User A has the `secret_key`, they can mint the tokens with that `tokenId`. Let's fix the minting amount to 1.
   * Mint 1 token to User B. -> User B balance of tokenId = 1 
   * Mint 1 token to User C. -> User C balance of tokenId = 1
 3. Now consider the case where User B transfers 1 token (tokenId) to User C. After the transfer:
 * User B balance of `tokenId` = 0
 * User C balance of `tokenId` = 2

I was exploring if there can be some way to differentiate between 2 tokens that User C holds i.e. difference between the one minted by User A and the one that is transferred by User B and could not figure out a way to make that happen.
In other words, I was looking if `address + tokenId` can be used as NFT Collection instead of a particular NFT.

Now what I understand from what you suggested is following:
1. User A generates key pair (which will have `tokenIdA`). User A mints 1 token with `tokenIdA`. User A balance of `tokenIdA` = 1
2. User B generates key pair (which will have `tokenIdB`). User B mints 1 token with `tokenIdB`. User B balance of `tokenIdB` = 1
3. User B transfers 1 token to User A. Then,
* User A balance of `tokenIdA` = 1; User A balance of `tokenIdB` = 1.
* User B balance of `tokenIdA` = 0; User B balance of `tokenIdB` = 0.

How will NFT Collection work in this case, where I want to create NFT Collection of 500 tokens. Do I create a 500 key pairs each minting 1 token of their derived tokenId? In such case how to track if all 500 key pairs belong to the same collection?
@maht0rz I have elaborated further on what I am trying to achieve and the problems I ran into.

Here's an example of what you could do:
- build an 'Airdrop NFT token contract', that holds a merkle root of people who can claim NFTs
- claiming an NFT would deploy a token account, under the token contract itself, showing 'who owns the token account' by providing a public key

- balance of the token is irelevant in this case, the ownership of an NFT is done through a property 'owner' on a token account thats a child of the collection

Something, something, what do you think?

This also gives you control over who can 'create' an NFT under the collection, since the NFT token contract controls what token accounts can be deployed, or what modifications can be done to them - e.g. ownership transfer
so you have an ownership link and a collections link, with control over the individual NFTs and no fungibility
its ofcourse a pretty naive architecture that i put together just as a response here, you'll have to go through the actual details yourself when designing it

@Prajwol G I have thought about the same problem. I think I have a design based on custom tokens and where a single contract controls an entire nft collection. nfts are stored either as app state on users accounts (implies a limit on number of nfts every user can hold) or as actions (unlimited, some implementation challenges) or off chain state. I can elaborate further another time but I think the version with actions can be very practical

Wow! Thank you. This is an interesting approach. 
Every new NFT will have an account creation fee associated with it. So practically, price of each NFT will be 1 MINA + (some arbitrary value).

Awesome! I think storing NFTs as app state might be very limiting as you mentioned. 
I would love to understand further on the design with actions as you suggested (really nice stuff 👏)  and the design seems to be rollup centric i.e. user makes txns that results in actions and it is rolled up with a separate tx. 
Is the design that you have in mind similar?
Yes I had a similar thing in mind

About, this, I understand: 
1) Actions are not limited in size as an account is, so you can store much more info in an NFT using an action. I have tried with big actions and so I am fairly certain about this point. I am right about this ? 
2) Actions will be stored in the archival nodes, so you can retrieve them from archival nodes at any time. Doubts: is there a way to identify a particular action, so I can retrieve it latter using (for example) some ID ? I know you can retrieve the list after some given point in time, but not clear if a particular action can be retrieved .
3) The order in which actions are processed can be different from the order in which they have been received. So this may block some features in some cases, for example you can not warrant that two transfers will be executed in the correct order (A -> B  then B->C) ? I am wrong with this ?

Yes, but please be aware that creating an account can take some time . In our credentials app we follow this approach and create a new account per credential claim, and in some cases (on Berkeley testnet) took around 10 minutes to create it (maybe is different in Mainnet). So your UI has to manage this waiting times in some way 🙂

About 3) this is from the MINA Docs "There is one interesting nuance here when compared to traditional Elm Architecture/Redux/useReducer instantiations: Because multiple actions are handled concurrently in an undefined order, it is important that actions commute against any possible state to prevent race conditions in your zkApp. Given any two actions a1 and a2 applying to some state s, s * a1 * a2 means the same as s * a2 * a1."
in https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/snarkyjs/actions-and-reducer

embeds.title: Mina Documentation
embeds.description: Website for documentation about Mina Protocol

messages.content: I think this implies 3) . Please correct me if I am wrong or misunderstood this from the docs.

This can be used but can be tricky  because you will only have the ID after the action has been dispatched. Don't know if you also have to wait for the transaction to complete before getting the last actionState after dispatching an action ?
2) Yeah true, you need to wait until the order of transactions in block is final.

3) Now I'm not sure as well, but my interpretation of docs is this:
If you send 2 transactions A and B in the order `(A, B)`, the order of transactions can be changed by block producer and therefore your operation on actions should be commutative, so the zkapp state should be same with the order `(B, A)`.

However, once the order has been established and you want to reduce pending actions in a zkapp, you need to do it in a correct order, so if in block the order is `(B, A)`, you need to reduce them in this order. Correct me on this one if I'm wrong.

The implication for NFTs would be that if you are trying to send a NFT from A -> B and B -> C in one block, you don't have a guarantee that it will pass, which makes sense.

Yes, that is what I understand too. Perhaps @gregor can clarify this for us 🙂 
There are cases when this is not critical at all. For example, in our app (basically a voting app) we have no problem with this. If A votes before B, but vote from B cames before vote from A in the fetchActions() list, it does not matter at all when finally counting votes. But this may not always be the case.

@Mario | Socialcap if each vote is an action thats dispatched, you MUST process them in the order they were processed in the block. Hence the name âsequence stateâ, they need to be processed in the same sequence otherwise sequence state precondition wont match
Your understanding is exactly right!

@maht0rz  I am ok with that. I process them in the order that reducer.getActions() gives them to me when doing the rollup, which I understand is the order in which each action was added in the block. That may not be the exact same order in which each transaction was started by the user, as  the order of transactions can be changed by the block producer. 
It is clear enough for me now. Thanks !
And this exactly was my concern on how to use actions for NFTs modeling. Would wait for @gregor to clarify his model that looks quite interesting to overcome the account state limitations !

Thanks for the heads up. 

I looked at the recent blocks on the Berkeley explorer (https://berkeley.minaexplorer.com/blocks) and noticed that the new blocks are created on Berkeley (not in ~ 3 minutes)  but in multiple of ~3 minutes. 
* Blocks created in 3 minutes [10010, 10007] 
* Blocks created in 6 minutes [10009, 10008, 10006]
* Blocks created in 9 minutes [10000, 9999]
* Blocks created in 12 minutes [9994]

Maybe the reason for 10 minutes is because that's how long it took to create the block including the transaction?

When we are generally making a tx on MINA, do we at least have to wait for 3 minutes?

As you suggested, that might change in the mainnet.

Also is it possible to share the github link to your credentials app?

Hi @Prajwol G , 
- about "...the reason for 10 minutes is ..." I can say is quite variable, the most it took was 10 minutes, but in other cases took less than that. 
- about "when we are generally making a tx on MINA, do we at least have to wait for 3 minutes?" Not quite sure about this, it usually takes "around" 3 minutes. I think it depends on many factors. 
- Github link is: https://github.com/Identicon-Dao/socialcap , but please look at branch `dev`
- Our proposal in Cohort1: https://zkignite.minaprotocol.com/zkignite/zkapp-track-1/funded/suggestion/271 
We are currently trying to define a Credential schema , thats my interest here and in an NFT standard 🙂

With the growing importance of credentials in Web3 communities as both a social and professional "signal" (as demonstrated by the popularity of POAPs and other NFTs used to show wealth or belonging), it's crucial to have a streamlined, tru...

messages.content: The VotingContract in folder /contracts uses actions+reducer

And the **draft** idea of the Credential schema is in `/contracts/src/CredentialContract.ts`

Will welcome any comments 🙂

Adding on top of this: 

How will the following conditions be handled?

1. A owns NFT `a`:
  tx1: A transfers `a` to B. 
  tx2: A transfer `a` to C.

i. Can both tx1 and tx2 be included in a block? Or is there any mechanism in the block that prevents it?
ii. If both tx1 and tx2 are included, I guess it will be upto the rollup to handle that.  I'm not so sure.

2. `NFT` contract exists (with ERC721 like interface)
    I create a `Marketplace` that should talk with the existing `NFT` contract. Say User A wants to do a buy NFT (listed by User B) on the Marketplace. Ideally the following actions should be atomic:
i. User A pays the specified amount to the `Marketplace`
ii. `Marketplace` takes % of the buy amount and sends the remaining amount to the User B.
iii. Ownership of `NFT` is transferred from User B -> User A.

With the actions-based approach, can we ensure such actions are atomic?

The case (2) is just an example. I want to discuss more broadly on how will **permissionless interoperability** be affected with actions-based approach.
Say a zkApp owns an two NFT of two different NFT Collections (say `NFT_A` of `CollectionA` and `NFT_B` of `CollectionB`); is it possible for the zkApp to do some actions on `NFT_A`(maybe transfer) + some other actions on `NFT_B` (maybe approve) on a single atomic transaction? Who will rollup txns on `CollectionA` and `CollectionB`? Do the rollup operators of `CollectionA` and `CollectionB` be in sync to allow for **interoperability**?

@Prajwol G actions do not necessarily involve a roll-up operator.

Also, you can structure your zkApp methods such that necessary conditions are already checked on action submission, not in the reducer method, and such that the reducer call will always be successful and can be done by anyone, most likely by the same user one block later
Oh okay! I didn't know that! Can you please explain a bit more on how that'll affect *interoperability between contracts* (if there's any)?
iâd suggest refraining from designing an action based rollup without an operator architecture. esp. if the state is merkle tree based
âanyone can rollup actionsâ = data availability problems to solve in that case
and if it isnt tree based state, but AU state, you still have the current AUs per TX limitation

@Prajwol G An *account* on Mina corresponds to a tuple (address, tokenId). So you when you have different tokenIds (say, for different nft collections), then there are different accounts.

Each of those accounts can have a different zkApp deployed to it, or not be a zkApp account at all. Therefore, it is difficult to speak of "interoperability between contracts" wrt tokens in generality since that already seems to assume that "one zkApp owns different tokens" which doesn't map to how contracts/tokens work on Mina

What we've been discussing here are "state stored in actions on user accounts" architectures. In that case concurrency isn't really an issue, because there's just one user interacting with the account

I'm not sure if I fully grasp the model you are suggesting.

What I have in mind (roughly) is:
Each NFT is a new address (zkApp). It'll have a few states including:
* owner -> NFT owner (in ERC721 sense)
* collectionAddress -> NFT Collection address

When transferring the NFT, user who owns the NFT can change the `owner` field but can never make changes to the `collectionAddress`. `collectionAddress` is assigned when minting and can never be changed.

What I understand about the approach you are suggesting is (Please correct me where I'm wrong):
All the NFTs owned by a user will be available to the user in a single address (say `NFTOwner` zkApp)
One obvious way to do that would have been to have `NFTOwner` will have nft1, nft2, .... nft8 as app state and we fill it up with different NFTs (allows upto only 8 NFTs).  So we instead store NFTs as actions instead. (that solves our limited NFTs issue). 

Could you explain a bit on how transfers will work with your approach?
(I assume approvals are not supported).

What I had in mind was to have an action to add an NFT to an account, and one to remove it. To prove that you own an NFT the token contract would go through all your nfts and check that it had been added but not removed.
A transfer would dispatch a remove action to one account and an add action to another account
There could also be a 'cleanup' method which would readd all currently available nfts without those that were sent away, so that you no longer have to process the removed ones
